newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan Chinese Petroleum posts Feb loss.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan Chinese Petroleum posts Feb loss.

text.p: Taiwan's state monopoly Chinese Petroleum Corp said on Saturday it posted a pre-tax loss of T$486 million in February, compared with a January pre-tax profit of T$308 million.

The figure contrasted with a targeted pre-tax profit of T$1.538 billion, despite an average nine percent domestic price increase on petroleum products that took effect on January 1, a company statement showed.
Chinese Petroleum's February oil import costs averaged US$22.59 per barrel, much higher than a budgeted US$15.26 per barrel, the statement said.
The firm has an accumulated deficit of T$1.965 billion from July to February. Chinese Petroleum calculates earning results based on a fiscal year of July to June.

The oil monopoly had targeted a profit of T$20.5 billion during the 1996/97 fiscal year. Under pressure to alleviate growing budgetary shortfalls, Chinese Petroleum petitioned the government in December for a price increase and was granted permission for an average nine percent rise, effective Jan 1.
The government also agreed to let Chinese Petroleum raise local oil prices further, but by no more than three percent, three months after the January rise.(US$1 = T$27.5)
